Jones, Andrzej S. Tarnawski VEGF-regulated angiogenesis is essential for embryonic development, wound healing and cancer growth. Serum response factor (SRF) is a serum inducible transcription factor important for embryonic development and muscle function. Its role in endothelial cell physiology, migration, proliferation, augiogenesis and potential interaction with VEGF remains unexplored. The aims of this study were to determine the role of SRF in angiogenesis, endothelial cell biology and its regulation by VEGF. METHODS: SRF deficiency was induced in rat gastric microvascular endothelial cells (RGMEC) by transfection with SRF ant/sense oligonudeotide. A complementary sense oligonucleotide was used as a control. STUDIES: The effect of SRF deficiency on: 1) VEGF-induced m vitro angiogenesis in RGMEC cells was evaluated by Matrigel assay; 2) VEGF-induced endothelial cell migration and proliferation was examined by wounding assay and 3H-thymidnie incorporation, respectively; and 3) VEGF-niduced expression of SRF-targeted genes such as c-Fos and Egr-1 analyzed by Western blotting. 4) Effect of VEGF on SRF expression was determined using RT-PCR, Western blot analysis and EMSA. 5) The signal transduction pathways mediating VEGF-niduced SRF activation were investigated using specific inhibitors for MEK-ERK and Rho-actin pathways. RESULTS: SRF deficiency inhibited VEGF-induced angiogenesis in vitro in RGMEC cells by 84 % (P < 0.001), reduced VEGF-induced endothelial cell migration by > 4 fold and proliferation by 40 % (both P < 0.001), and inhibited VEGF-induced G-actni polymerization and activation of c-Fos and Egr-1. VEGF treatment induced SRF expression by 7 fold and activated SRF nuclear translocation and DNA binding activity. This activation was completely abolished by MEK inhibitor U0126 and PD98059, Rho GTPase inhibitor Clostridium difficile toxin B, and actin polymerization inhibitor Latranculin B. CONCLUSIONS: 1) SRF is a down stream mediator of VEGF signaling and a critical requirement for VEGF-induced angiogenesis; 2) VEGF-induced endothelial cell migration is dependent on SRF activation; 3) SRF is important for VEGF-induced endothelial cell proliferation; and 4) VEGF promotes SRF expression, nuclear translocation and DNA binding activity in endothelial cells through both Rho-actin and MEK-ERK dependent signaling pathways.W1042Substance P May Promote Intraabdominal Adhesion Formation by Decreasing Peritoneal Fibrinolytic Activity Karen L. FIGREF90.text: Secretion of White Adipose Tissue in Intestinal Inflammation ex viva and Investigation of Its Proinflammatory Effects in VitroGisela Paul, Angela Ehfing, Ulf Mueller-Ladner, Gerhard Rogler, Juergen Schoelmerich, Andreas Schaeffler, Hans Herfarth Background: Transformations of the white adipose tissue (WAT) of the mesentery in patients suffering of Crohn's disease (CD) known as creeping fat are well known. This WAT hypertrophy points to a functional role of adipocytes or adipocytokines, e.g. Adiponectin (AN), in intestinal inflammation. AN is a protein strictly secreted by adipocytes that is part of the Clq/TNF superfamily. We evaluated the secretion of AN by WAT in patients with CD, diverticulitis (D1V) and controls (CO) ex vivo. Secondly, the effects of AN on the secretion of IL-6 were investigated in two different cell lines in vitro. Methods: Tissue specimens of WAT of 3 patients with CD, 2 patients with DIV and 5 CO (non-inflamed WAT of patients with colon carcinoma) were obtained by laparotomy and incubated for 24 hours. The concentration of AN was determined in the supernatant by ELISA. MonoMac6-cells (a myelo-monocytic cell line) and HT29 cells (an epithelial cell line) were stimulated with 10 ng/ml lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and increasing concentrations of AN. As a control, cells were also incubated in the presence of a specific neutralizing antibody against AN. Results: In the supernatant of the fat tissue cultures of patients with CD as well as of patients with DIV, the concentration of AN (Irg/g fat tissue; mean _+ SEM) was significantly elevated in comparison with CO (1421 _+ 173 (CD); 1275 _4-178 (DIV) vs 932 + 109 (CO); p<O.02). In vitro there was no detectable IL-6 secretion by both cell lines after stimulation with AN alone. However, in both cell lines a dose dependent additive effect of AN on the LPS stimulated secretion of 1L-6 could be detected (p<0.02). This effect could be reversed by neutralizing AN with a specific antibody. Conclusion: WAT cultures of patients with CD and DIV as well as the demonstrated additive effect of AN with LPS incubation on the IL-6 production indicate an involvement of WAT and its secreted adipocytokines in intestinal inflammation. However, the preliminary ex vivo results do not point to a specific role of AN during chronic intestinal inflammation. NewberryPurpose: Isolated lymphoid follicles (1LEs) are organized tertiary lymphoid structures in the small intestine. The formation of ILFs is characterized by a progression from clusters of B220 + cells, immature ILFs (iiLFs), to an organized lymphoid stmcture possessing an overlying follicle associated epithelium, mature ILFs (mILFs). The formation of ILFs is known to be dependent upon lymphotoxin beta receptor (LTI3R) expression by intestinal stromal cells. The formation of mILFs is known to require lymphotoxin (LT) sufficient B-cells, however the requirement for LT sufficient B-cells in the formation of iILFs is unknown. The induction of LT expression in B-cells can occur following B-cell activation by B-cell receptor crosslinking and CD40 figation. Alternatively the induction of LT expression in B-cell can occur following chemokine ligation. We sought to determine the requirement for LT sufficient B-cell in the formation of ilLFs, and to determine the requirement for antigen specific Bcell and T-cell stimulation in the formation of iILFs and mILFs. Methods: Mice expressing exclusively a transgenic B-cell receptor specific for hen egg lysozyme, MD4JH-/-mice, and mice expressing exclusively a transgenic T-cell receptor specific for a peptide o f hen egg lysozyme presented in the context of 1-Ak, 3AgTCRoL-/-mice, were examine for the presence of ilLFs and mlLFs using whole mount techniques with anti-B220 staining and UEA-I lectin staining. Lethally irradiated LT~-/-mice receiving LT~-/-bone marrow, C57BL/6 bone marrow, or a combination of LTo~-/-and JH-/-bone marrow were examined for the presence of ilLFs and mILFs. Findings: We observed that ilLFs and mlLF formation was preserved in MD4JH-/-and 3A9Ka-/-mice. Immature and mature ILFs were observed in the intestines of LTa-/-mice receiving C57BL/6 bone marrow. Immature 1LFs but not mlLFs were present in LTa-/-recipients of a combination of LTa-/-and JH-/-bone marrow. Both ilLFs and m ILFs were absent in intestines of LTot-/-mice receiving LT(x-/-bone marrow. Conclusions: These findings demonstrate that antigen specific B-cell and T-cell events are not required for the formation of ilLFs and mILFs. In the absence of LT sufficient B-cells ILF formation is arrested at the iILF stage. Colt Isolated from Crohn's Disease patients Isabelle lngrassia, Antony Leplingard, Arlette Darfeuille-Michaud BACKGROUND: Ileal lesions of Crohn's disease (CD) are abnormally colonized by adherentinvasive E. coil (AIEC) strains, able to adhere to and to invade cultured intestinal epithelial cells. Probiotics are effective tools for preventing infections and their efficacy in inflammatory bowel disease has been reported. AIM: To determine the in vitro inhibitory effects of the probiotic strain Lactobacillas easel (L casei) DN-114 001 on adhesion to and invasion of human intestinal epithelial ceils by AIEC strains isolated from ileal lesions of CD patients. METHOD: Bacterial adhesion to and invasion of the intestinal epithelial cells Caco-2 were assessed by numbering colony forming units. Inhibitory effects of L. case/ DN-114 001 bacteria alone, or in the presence of its culture supematant, on AIEC adhesion to and invasion of the intestinal epithelial ceils Caco-2, HT29 and Intestine-407 were determined in pre-and co-incubation experiments. RESULTS: In co-incubation, using Caco-2 cells, inhibitory effects of L case/DN-114 001 alone on AIEC LF-82 adhesion and invasion reached 82% and 79%, respectively. Inhibitory assays realized in the presence of L. case/ DN-114 001 bacteria and 10% of L case/ DN-114 001 culture supematant revealed very strong inhibitory effects on LF-82 adhesion and invasion (90% and 93%, respectively). In preincubation, inhibitory effects of L case/DN-114 001 alone on LF-82 adhesion and invasion reached 47% and 56% respectively, and 73% and 89% respectively when supernatant was added. The increased inhibitory effects of L. case/ DN-114 001 in the presence of its supernatant was not due to a bactericidal effect on AIEC LF82 or a cytotoxic effect on Caco-2 cells. It was associated with an increased adhesion of L casei DN-114 001 to intestinal epithelial cells and an additional inhibitory effect of the supematant by itself. Similar results were observed with various AIEC strains and others intestinal cell lines (HT-29 and Intestine-407). CONCLUSION: The probiotic L case/DN-114 001 strongly inhibits AIEC adhesion to and invasion of intestinal epithelial cells, indicating that it could prevent intestinal colonization and invasion of the gut mucosa by AIEC strains and be beneficial in inflammatory bowel disease. back_matter.text: LFA-1 and in vivo T Cell Activation Sravanthi Kandula, Clara AbrahamThe leukocyte specific integrin, LEAd t ..... (CDI la/CD18), plays a 'crmcal role m trafflckmg to both lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues. As such, it has been targeted in therapy of irdlammatory diseases, including 1BD, in both animal models and human disease. However, in addition to its role as a trafficking molecule, there is substantial in vitro evidence that LEA-1 can contribute to T cell activation, both in its role as an adhesion molecule, and through other non-adhesive mechanisms. Therefore, it is important to understand the consequences of targeting LEA-1 in disease therapy, in terms of the spectrum of impact on immune cell trafficking, as well as the effect on other immune responses. At this time, the contribution of LFA-1 to T cell activation, in particular CD4+ T cell activation, in vivo has been less clear. There are numerous reports describing T cell response defects in vivo; however, due to the severe T cell migration defect to lymphoid structures in the absence of LEA-l, it has been difficult to dissect if there is also a T cell activation deficit contributing to the in vivo T cell function defects observed. Specifically, the decreased number of T cells in the lymph nodes and various other lymphoid sites secondary to the migration defect may be the dominant etiology of the defect in T cell responses. To investigate the role of LFA-1 in vivo, we used mice deficient in CD18, such that no 1.FA-1 is expressed on the cell surface. The ED18-/-mice were then crossed to DO11.10 T cell receptor (TCR) transgenic mice, which encode an ovalbumin-specific, lAd-restricted TCR. This system allows for segregating the tmgration defect from the T cell activation defect as there is an antibody directed to the DOl1.10 TCR, and we are able to follow these antigen-specific T cells in vivo. Cell division was used as a measure of T cell activation by utilizing CFSE-labeled DO11.10 CD4 + T cells. We have found that CESE-labeled CD18-/-CD4+ DOll.10 T cells adoptively transferred into wild-type mice have a defect in reaching later cell divisions in the peripheral lymph nodes upon immunization with subcutaneous LPS/ovalbumin. Furthermore, the defect in CD18-/-CD4+ DO11.10 T cell activation is more severe upon IV kPS/ovalbumin immunization. The CD18-/-T cell activation defects are accompanied by functional consequences in IFN-T production and antibody isotype switching. Therefore, in addition to the significant role LFA-1 plays in naive T cell migration to peripheral lymph nodes, we demonstrate that it is clearly also important for CD4 + T cell activation in vivo. compared to normal rats. Butyrate Mediated Phosphorylation and Targeting of Hsp25 to Mitochondria in IEC-18 Cells: Role of p38 MAP Kinase Mark ]. Ropeleski Background: The induction of Hsp25 by butyrate is associated with increased epithelial resistance to injury. While the functional compartmentalization of Hsp25 in the IEC-18 cell is unknown, it may involve p38 MAP kinase-mediated alterations in Hsp25 phosphorylation. We hypothesized that changes in Hsp25 phosphorylation may mediate the protective properties of butyrate. Methods: IEC-18 cells were treated with butyrate for 6-24 hrs. Immunolocalization of Hsp25 was carried out by confocal laser microscopy. Hsp25 phosphorylation was examined using 2-D iso-electric focusing gel electrophoresis. The accumulation of Hsp25 in cytoskeletal-enriched fractions was examined in Triton X-IO0 insoluble protein fractions. Hsp25 accumulation in mitochondrial-enriched fractions was studied by immunoblotting. The activation of p38 MAP kinase by butyrate was determined using phospho-specific antibodies. Results: Treatment of IEC-18 cells with butyrate resulted in the generalized accumulation of Hsp25 in the cell at 12-24 hrs by Western blot and confocal microscopy. Hsp25 did not concentrate in Triton X-IO0 insoluble fractions. Hsp25 did accumulate in mitochondrial-enriched fractions, an event that was paralleled by the accumulation of phosphorylated Hsp25 isoforms at 12-24 hrs. p38 MAPK phosphorylation also coincided with changes in Hsp25 while the accumulation of phospho-Hsp25 was partially attenuated by the inhibitor SB203580. Conclusion: Butyrate mediated changes in Hsp25 phosphorylation are associated with Hsp25 enrichment of mitochondrial fractions. This phosphorylation appears to coincide with and partially depend on the activation of the p38 MAP kinase. We speculate that the targeting of Hsp25 by butyrate to mitochondria in order to antagonize ensuing cytochrome c release, assembly of the apoptosome and/or caspase activation during pro-apoptotic intestinal epithelial cell stress in inflammation may be an important path of cellular defense in non-transformed cells.
